title: How to Make Heart Shaped Quesadillas

methods.name: Making Simple Heart Shaped Cheese Quesadillas

steps.headline: Cut your tortillas into hearts using a heart shaped cookie cutter.
steps.description: Lay out your 8 tortillas onto a cutting board and press down on the surface of the tortilla with a heart shaped cookie cutter. You can purchase heart shaped cookie cutters online or at most major department and craft stores. Layer a couple of tortillas over each other to cut them faster.

steps.headline: Lay your heart tortillas onto a greased cooking sheet.
steps.description: Grease a standard 9 x 13 in (22.9 x 33 cm) cooking sheet with a cooking spray or olive oil so that your tortillas don't stick to the pan as they cook.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the grated cheddar on the tortillas.
steps.description: Put the cheese in the center of the tortilla in a little pile. Try to get an even distribution of cheese on all the tortillas so that they taste similar.

steps.headline: Place another heart tortilla over the cheese.
steps.description: Line up 8 more of your tortilla hearts and place them over the existing tortillas with cheese on your cooking sheet. This will complete the preparation portion for your quesadillas.

steps.headline: Heat your oven to 325°F (162.7°C) and cook for three minutes.
steps.description: Preheat your oven and bring it up to 325°F (162.7°C). Place the cooking sheet on the middle rack and continue to cook them for three minutes. Once they are done cooking, take them out and allow them to cool. The cheese inside of the quesadilla should be completely melted.

steps.headline: Allow quesadillas to cool and serve.
steps.description: Allow your quesadillas to cool for a minute. Do not let your quesadillas sit for too long before serving, because the cheese will harden as it's out of the oven. Sprinkle salt over the top of your quesadillas to finish seasoning them and serve them.

steps.headline: Cut your tortilla into a large heart shape.
steps.description: Use a sharp pointed knife to cut out a heart shape over a cutting board. The heart should take up the majority of the tortilla. The smaller that you cut the heart, the smaller your quesadilla will be.

steps.headline: Brush one side of each tortilla.
steps.description: You should only brush one side of the tortilla so that the other side of your quesadilla is dry and cool enough to be eaten with your hands. If you don't have a cooking brush, you can use a napkin, paper towels, or your hands to spread olive oil over the surface of your tortilla.

steps.headline: Fry bacon on the stovetop.
steps.description: Lay your bacon onto a hot skillet and cook each side for 7-8 minutes or until it becomes crispy and brown. If you like crispier bacon, allow it to cook for a minute or two extra on each side before taking it out of the pan. Set your bacon aside in a bowl lined with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Fry the tortilla on the stovetop on high until brown.
steps.description: You will only need to cook one side of each piece of tortilla that you have. The heat generated from cooking that side of the tortilla will melt the cheese once you sprinkle it over the tortilla.

steps.headline: Spread the Primula cheese over the tortilla.
steps.description: Use a knife to cut into the Primula cheese. Primula cheese is a soft Norwegian cheese that's easily spreadable. Spread the cheese over the cooked side of the tortilla. If you can't get Primula cheese, you can replace it with another soft spreadable cheese like Manouri, Brie, or Brillat-Savarin.

steps.headline: Put bacon and apple slices over the cheese.
steps.description: Remove your bacon from the bowl that you set aside and place it over the tortilla covered in cheese. Line up the apple slices so that there's an even distribution over the tortilla.

steps.headline: Place another tortilla over the top and serve.
steps.description: Place the other tortilla cooked side down and press down on your quesadilla. Allow it to cool for another minute before serving it. The soft cheese and bacon will add a smoky saltiness, so no seasoning is required.

steps.headline: Cut your tortillas into a heart shape.
steps.description: Stack your tortillas up and use a cookie cutter or a knife to cut out hearts from them. Stacking the tortillas up when cutting them will make them uniform.

steps.headline: Heat cooking oil in a skillet over the stovetop.
steps.description: Heat oil on medium to high heat until it starts to smoke lightly. Do not leave the oil on the stovetop for too long or it will burn and will make your food taste burnt.

steps.headline: Sauté onions and garlic until translucent.
steps.description: Add your diced onions and garlic into your pan with the hot oil and continue to cook them to release their aromatic flavors. Continue cooking them on medium-high for two to three minutes.

steps.headline: Add the black beans, corn, and spices.
steps.description: Cook the mixture on medium heat for about two minutes. Add your 1 tsp. (2.6 g) of chili powder, 1 tsp. (2.6 g) of cumin, and ½ tsp. (1.3 g) of salt until they are well incorporated into the mixture. Continue to mix everything and then reduce the heat to low and continue to cook it for about three more minutes. Remember to drain the black beans before using them.

steps.headline: Toast one side of each heart shaped tortilla.
steps.description: Pour a tablespoon (14.7 ml) of oil to a pan and heat it on medium-high for about two minutes. Place your tortillas face down into the oil in the pan for two more minutes or until they are crispy and brown. Remove the tortillas once they are cooked and set them aside on a paper towel-lined plate.

steps.headline: Spread your soft cheese on the cooked side.
steps.description: Wait for the tortilla to cool before spreading your soft cheese onto the cooked side of each tortilla. The heat from the tortillas should make the cheese melt onto it.

steps.headline: Top the tortilla with the black bean and corn mixture.
steps.description: Take half of your bean mixture and pour it over the cheese on one tortilla. Transfer the rest of your black bean and corn mixture to the other tortilla.

steps.headline: Garnish the quesadilla with tomato, onions, and cilantro.
steps.description: Add some freshly chopped onions and tomatoes to the top of your black bean mixture. This will add a burst of freshness to your quesadilla. Finish the dish off by adding a little cilantro to the top.

steps.headline: Place the other tortilla on the top of your garnish.
steps.description: Finish sealing off your quesadilla by placing the other half of the tortilla over both of your black bean covered tortillas. Press down to make the quesadilla flat, then serve.

steps.headline: Finished.

text: Making Simple Heart Shaped Cheese Quesadillas Cut your tortillas into hearts using a heart shaped cookie cutter. Lay out your 8 tortillas onto a cutting board and press down on the surface of the tortilla with a heart shaped cookie cutter. You can purchase heart shaped cookie cutters online or at most major department and craft stores. Layer a couple of tortillas over each other to cut them faster. Lay your heart tortillas onto a greased cooking sheet. Grease a standard 9 x 13 in (22.9 x 33 cm) cooking sheet with a cooking spray or olive oil so that your tortillas don't stick to the pan as they cook. Sprinkle the grated cheddar on the tortillas. Put the cheese in the center of the tortilla in a little pile. Try to get an even distribution of cheese on all the tortillas so that they taste similar. Place another heart tortilla over the cheese. Line up 8 more of your tortilla hearts and place them over the existing tortillas with cheese on your cooking sheet. This will complete the preparation portion for your quesadillas. Heat your oven to 325°F (162.7°C) and cook for three minutes. Preheat your oven and bring it up to 325°F (162.7°C). Place the cooking sheet on the middle rack and continue to cook them for three minutes. Once they are done cooking, take them out and allow them to cool. The cheese inside of the quesadilla should be completely melted. Allow quesadillas to cool and serve. Allow your quesadillas to cool for a minute. Do not let your quesadillas sit for too long before serving, because the cheese will harden as it's out of the oven. Sprinkle salt over the top of your quesadillas to finish seasoning them and serve them. Making Bacon and Cheese Quesadillas Cut your tortilla into a large heart shape. Use a sharp pointed knife to cut out a heart shape over a cutting board. The heart should take up the majority of the tortilla. The smaller that you cut the heart, the smaller your quesadilla will be. Brush one side of each tortilla. You should only brush one side of the tortilla so that the other side of your quesadilla is dry and cool enough to be eaten with your hands. If you don't have a cooking brush, you can use a napkin, paper towels, or your hands to spread olive oil over the surface of your tortilla. Fry bacon on the stovetop. Lay your bacon onto a hot skillet and cook each side for 7-8 minutes or until it becomes crispy and brown. If you like crispier bacon, allow it to cook for a minute or two extra on each side before taking it out of the pan. Set your bacon aside in a bowl lined with a paper towel. Fry the tortilla on the stovetop on high until brown. You will only need to cook one side of each piece of tortilla that you have. The heat generated from cooking that side of the tortilla will melt the cheese once you sprinkle it over the tortilla. Spread the Primula cheese over the tortilla. Use a knife to cut into the Primula cheese. Primula cheese is a soft Norwegian cheese that's easily spreadable. Spread the cheese over the cooked side of the tortilla. If you can't get Primula cheese, you can replace it with another soft spreadable cheese like Manouri, Brie, or Brillat-Savarin. Put bacon and apple slices over the cheese. Remove your bacon from the bowl that you set aside and place it over the tortilla covered in cheese. Line up the apple slices so that there's an even distribution over the tortilla. Place another tortilla over the top and serve. Place the other tortilla cooked side down and press down on your quesadilla. Allow it to cool for another minute before serving it. The soft cheese and bacon will add a smoky saltiness, so no seasoning is required. Cooking Vegan Heart Shaped Quesadillas Cut your tortillas into a heart shape. Stack your tortillas up and use a cookie cutter or a knife to cut out hearts from them. Stacking the tortillas up when cutting them will make them uniform. Heat cooking oil in a skillet over the stovetop. Heat oil on medium to high heat until it starts to smoke lightly. Do not leave the oil on the stovetop for too long or it will burn and will make your food taste burnt. Sauté onions and garlic until translucent. Add your diced onions and garlic into your pan with the hot oil and continue to cook them to release their aromatic flavors. Continue cooking them on medium-high for two to three minutes. Add the black beans, corn, and spices. Cook the mixture on medium heat for about two minutes. Add your 1 tsp. (2.6 g) of chili powder, 1 tsp. (2.6 g) of cumin, and ½ tsp. (1.3 g) of salt until they are well incorporated into the mixture. Continue to mix everything and then reduce the heat to low and continue to cook it for about three more minutes. Remember to drain the black beans before using them. Toast one side of each heart shaped tortilla. Pour a tablespoon (14.7 ml) of oil to a pan and heat it on medium-high for about two minutes. Place your tortillas face down into the oil in the pan for two more minutes or until they are crispy and brown. Remove the tortillas once they are cooked and set them aside on a paper towel-lined plate. Spread your soft cheese on the cooked side. Wait for the tortilla to cool before spreading your soft cheese onto the cooked side of each tortilla. The heat from the tortillas should make the cheese melt onto it. Top the tortilla with the black bean and corn mixture. Take half of your bean mixture and pour it over the cheese on one tortilla. Transfer the rest of your black bean and corn mixture to the other tortilla. Garnish the quesadilla with tomato, onions, and cilantro. Add some freshly chopped onions and tomatoes to the top of your black bean mixture. This will add a burst of freshness to your quesadilla. Finish the dish off by adding a little cilantro to the top. Place the other tortilla on the top of your garnish. Finish sealing off your quesadilla by placing the other half of the tortilla over both of your black bean covered tortillas. Press down to make the quesadilla flat, then serve. Finished.
sentences: Making Simple Heart Shaped Cheese Quesadillas Cut your tortillas into hearts using a heart shaped cookie cutter.
Lay out your 8 tortillas onto a cutting board and press down on the surface of the tortilla with a heart shaped cookie cutter.
You can purchase heart shaped cookie cutters online or at most major department and craft stores.
Layer a couple of tortillas over each other to cut them faster.
Lay your heart tortillas onto a greased cooking sheet.
Grease a standard 9 x 13 in (22.9 x 33 cm) cooking sheet with a cooking spray or olive oil so that your tortillas don't stick to the pan as they cook.
Sprinkle the grated cheddar on the tortillas.
Put the cheese in the center of the tortilla in a little pile.
Try to get an even distribution of cheese on all the tortillas so that they taste similar.
Place another heart tortilla over the cheese.
Line up 8 more of your tortilla hearts and place them over the existing tortillas with cheese on your cooking sheet.
This will complete the preparation portion for your quesadillas.
Heat your oven to 325°F (162.7°C) and cook for three minutes.
Preheat your oven and bring it up to 325°F (162.7°C).
Place the cooking sheet on the middle rack and continue to cook them for three minutes.
Once they are done cooking, take them out and allow them to cool.
The cheese inside of the quesadilla should be completely melted.
Allow quesadillas to cool and serve.
Allow your quesadillas to cool for a minute.
Do not let your quesadillas sit for too long before serving, because the cheese will harden as it's out of the oven.
Sprinkle salt over the top of your quesadillas to finish seasoning them and serve them.
Making Bacon and Cheese Quesadillas Cut your tortilla into a large heart shape.
Use a sharp pointed knife to cut out a heart shape over a cutting board.
The heart should take up the majority of the tortilla.
The smaller that you cut the heart, the smaller your quesadilla will be.
Brush one side of each tortilla.
You should only brush one side of the tortilla so that the other side of your quesadilla is dry and cool enough to be eaten with your hands.
If you don't have a cooking brush, you can use a napkin, paper towels, or your hands to spread olive oil over the surface of your tortilla.
Fry bacon on the stovetop.
Lay your bacon onto a hot skillet and cook each side for 7-8 minutes or until it becomes crispy and brown.
If you like crispier bacon, allow it to cook for a minute or two extra on each side before taking it out of the pan.
Set your bacon aside in a bowl lined with a paper towel.
Fry the tortilla on the stovetop on high until brown.
You will only need to cook one side of each piece of tortilla that you have.
The heat generated from cooking that side of the tortilla will melt the cheese once you sprinkle it over the tortilla.
Spread the Primula cheese over the tortilla.
Use a knife to cut into the Primula cheese.
Primula cheese is a soft Norwegian cheese that's easily spreadable.
Spread the cheese over the cooked side of the tortilla.
If you can't get Primula cheese, you can replace it with another soft spreadable cheese like Manouri, Brie, or Brillat-Savarin.
Put bacon and apple slices over the cheese.
Remove your bacon from the bowl that you set aside and place it over the tortilla covered in cheese.
Line up the apple slices so that there's an even distribution over the tortilla.
Place another tortilla over the top and serve.
Place the other tortilla cooked side down and press down on your quesadilla.
Allow it to cool for another minute before serving it.
The soft cheese and bacon will add a smoky saltiness, so no seasoning is required.
Cooking Vegan Heart Shaped Quesadillas Cut your tortillas into a heart shape.
Stack your tortillas up and use a cookie cutter or a knife to cut out hearts from them.
Stacking the tortillas up when cutting them will make them uniform.
Heat cooking oil in a skillet over the stovetop.
Heat oil on medium to high heat until it starts to smoke lightly.
Do not leave the oil on the stovetop for too long or it will burn and will make your food taste burnt.
Sauté onions and garlic until translucent.
Add your diced onions and garlic into your pan with the hot oil and continue to cook them to release their aromatic flavors.
Continue cooking them on medium-high for two to three minutes.
Add the black beans, corn, and spices.
Cook the mixture on medium heat for about two minutes.
Add your 1 tsp.
(2.6 g) of chili powder, 1 tsp.
(2.6 g) of cumin, and ½ tsp.
(1.3 g) of salt until they are well incorporated into the mixture.
Continue to mix everything and then reduce the heat to low and continue to cook it for about three more minutes.
Remember to drain the black beans before using them.
Toast one side of each heart shaped tortilla.
Pour a tablespoon (14.7 ml) of oil to a pan and heat it on medium-high for about two minutes.
Place your tortillas face down into the oil in the pan for two more minutes or until they are crispy and brown.
Remove the tortillas once they are cooked and set them aside on a paper towel-lined plate.
Spread your soft cheese on the cooked side.
Wait for the tortilla to cool before spreading your soft cheese onto the cooked side of each tortilla.
The heat from the tortillas should make the cheese melt onto it.
Top the tortilla with the black bean and corn mixture.
Take half of your bean mixture and pour it over the cheese on one tortilla.
Transfer the rest of your black bean and corn mixture to the other tortilla.
Garnish the quesadilla with tomato, onions, and cilantro.
Add some freshly chopped onions and tomatoes to the top of your black bean mixture.
This will add a burst of freshness to your quesadilla.
Finish the dish off by adding a little cilantro to the top.
Place the other tortilla on the top of your garnish.
Finish sealing off your quesadilla by placing the other half of the tortilla over both of your black bean covered tortillas.
Press down to make the quesadilla flat, then serve.
Finished.
